I have looked at a lot of videos about colonizing the moon & Mars. And I haven't found any with my same ideas. I think we should set up a moon colony on earth. We should have inflatable domes, which we cover with 3D printers with simulated moon mortar. The domes should be connected to each other by inflatable tunnels covered with simulated moon mortar. There should be living quarters, hydroponic green houses, gardens with garden soil for recreational gardening, a 5 acre pasture with one inch of garden soil and one inch of grass turf, a park with artificial turf and with small sections of real grass turf, and maybe even a very small zoo. All the domes will have plastic floors so no water is lost. Condensation forming on the ceilings will be drained into the water supply. All the domes will be blown up with compressed air from earth and will have a refresh system, which will refresh the air and maintain the air pressure. Humidity, Temperature will be maintained by humidifiers, heaters, fans and coolers. Light will be provided by multi-color LEDs, mostly white. Power will be supplied at first by solar power, and later by nuclear or fusion power. All water will be re-cycled, almost zero loss of water. There will be a bull, a cow, two sheep, and two goats, two chickens, two turkeys, two fish, and two rabbits. There will also be pets, two dogs, two cats, two bunnies, etc. (and maybe a small zoo) All of this will be set up by astronauts and robots before the colonist arrive.

The first colonist will be 5 fathers and 5 mothers, and 90 babies. The parents will be good parents, gardeners, farmers, zoo keepers, teachers, etc.. During the first two years an exact duplicate facility will be built on the moon. When the babies are two years old, they will move to the moon and live on the moon. Or if it is proven that they will be too young to travel to the moon than the facility on earth will be added to, to accommodate 10 more parents and 90 more babies. The two year olds would move into the new addition. Every two years the facility will be either added to, or 100 people will move to the moon. This plan will allow the kids to grow up in the isolation of the colony, and will make it easier for them to live in the isolation of the colony on the moon. And will allow them to grow up on the moon and be better able to adjust to the lower gravity on the moon, although some artificial gravity maybe eventually provided. This artificial gravity will especially be good for the parents. The kids will have everything in the facility to keep them occupied and entertained. Also they could have some books, movies, games, etc., especially adapted for them, being careful not to give them anything that would make them feel isolated.

After 20 years there could be 2000 people living on the moon, most of whom grew up on the moon. This program could be speeded up so in 20 years there could be 4000, 6000, or 8000 people living on the moon.

This program could be simultaneously done to colonize Mars so we could have 2000 people on the Moon and Mars at the same time. For the moon we could send supplies every month, but for Mars we could only send supplies every 26 months. So I suggest we send 10, 20, or 30 rockets to Mars every 26 months all at the same time.

We could have several refueling stations along the way to mars and orbiting mars so rockets could refuel along the way to mars and right before landing on mars so the empty rocket would have enough fuel to take off again, refuel in space and return to Earth. Eventually the colonist could grow trees, bamboo, and other plants for raw materials that could be used for making things. Eventually the moon and Mars could export minerals or small expensive items that were assembled on the moon or Mars, like jewelry, iphones, iwatches, etc. Or grown on the moon like caviar, marijuana, etc.

Very late comment but... Thrust and therefore Isp improve in a vacuum even without increasing expansion ratio, so the BFR upper-stage engines should do better than 330 sec there. For example, the Merlin 1D's Isp improves from 282 sec (SL) to 311 sec (vac) even with the 16:1 bell, and then to 348 sec (vac) with the 165:1 bell.

So as a bottom line, I would expect Isp = 350 sec in vacuum or maybe a touch better for those "sea-level" engines.

Mass to orbit reduction fully explained by the change to all sea level optimized engines - Assuming 1/2 of orbital velocity is provided by the BFS, fuel requirements go from 65% of mass (at 380s ISP) to 70% of mass (at 340s ISP). That extra 4-5% of starting mass has to be taken from payload capacity, since the lower stage isn't getting larger.  Interesting trade off! Also means SpaceEx could increase payload mass to equal the 2nd generation SLS, just by changing the engines to space optimized ones, and eliminating the rear payload bay.

Back to rocket design; especially landing boosters for re-use.  I really think it is unwise to land standing up.  Landing should be a two step operation where once you stick the touchdown; you immediately lay down horizontally and not remain vertical, which is most unstable.  This technique almost designs itself.   Two - four lay-down boosters: two to control laying down into the wind and two for actually easing the lay-down that are 180° apart.  You need enough thrust for about a 20 second transition thrust.  Extra legs 3/4 of the way up the booster to carry the mid-load.

Space X keeps changing their designs because Blue Origin hasn't made an orbital flight yet...
... and they don't want to be like them.

Blue Origin has committed to incremental advancement. Something is done.. it's done to plan, it's done perfectly.. and then it's tested in infinitum until it meets the numbers it's supposed to.
Space X stuck the parts together.. blew it up.. rebuilt it after figuring out what blew up.. got one that didn't blow up.. measured the thrust and weight... and built a rocket around that.

Wash.. rinse.. repeat.
It's said that no two rockets that Space X has ever built have been the same... until this most recent iteration of Falcon 9.

In the immortal words of agent Smith... "One of these lives has a future... the other... does not".

Excuse me, may I correct you regarding the rocket engine comparison at 11:00? The chamber pressure of RD-170 - first flown in 1985 - is 250 bar. The Raptor is now tested at 200 bar, is aimed for 250 bar (still not flown) and is expected to reach 300 bar in future iterations (Hollywood stuff). Citation Wikipedia: "The test engine operates at 20 MPa (200 bar; 2,900 psi) pressure. The flight engine is aimed for 25 MPa (250 bar; 3,600 psi), and SpaceX expects to achieve 30 MPa (300 bar; 4,400 psi) in later iterations." If the Raptor flies in 2020 and reaches 250 bar, that means SpaceX reach the russian state-of-the-art from 1985 and is 35 years behind RU in some technological aspects. Since we are not in Hollywood, you should remove the Raptor and the fantasy of 300 bar and put it between RS-25 and Merlin where it actually belongs!

Because the ITS/BFR announcements have much more to do with generating publicity/enthusiasm than promoting a specific product. Since SpaceX does not have the resources to develop a cleansheet super-heavy rocket right now (Falcon Heavy was completely derived from Falcon 9 hardware), they have to pitch a bunch of concepts in the meantime to keep the headlines and online discussions going.

Graphics and animated concept videos are cheap and can be turned around quickly. Flight prototypes are not. So we're seeing a new concept each year until SpaceX finally arrives at what their investors will agree to fund.

The ITS concept was created to sell the vision of Mars settlement. The 2017 BFR was sized to an Airbus A380 cabin and used to sell the idea of rockets replacing airplanes. When it became clear to everyone that neither scenario was actually going to happen in the next 10 years, Elon pivoted to lunar tourism. It had plenty of potential customers since the 2017 announcement and had reasonable life support requirements comparable to Dragon's.

And because this version of BFR needed to be sized for TLI, not LEO, like the P2P transport BFR, it needed to be stretched. More fuel for the first stage (which would be expended) and for the second stage to enable TLI and fuel margins for propulsive landing. The tanker was thrown out completely for lunar tourism, as SpaceX has no on-orbit refueling experience and refueling would be a major inconvenience to the passengers.

Everyone asking about funding was raising an important point, though. This can't happen without billions of dollars in support, and even in a best-case engineering lifecycle, development timelines are tied to annual funding. So by asking about funding, press members were asking how seriously they should take THIS proposal compared to the previous two.

Personally, I wouldn't be surprised if SpaceX needs to scale BFR down even more to something that would directly replace the Falcon rockets. Elon didn't seem so confident that investors would buy his "cheaper than a Falcon 1" argument from the 2017 talk.

It's just more cost-effective (and more environmentally sustainable) for SpaceX to build a fully reusable vehicle that would compete directly with New Glenn. And its payload to LEO would be comparable to Falcon Heavy's expendable load, making it sufficient for launching StarLink.

But Elon can't announce that yet because it's not as exciting or headline-grabbing as a Saturn V-class reusable rocket. So he can't publicly concede to building a slightly smaller Falcon-sized vehicle until competition with Blue Origin pressures them to do otherwise. That's another reason the development timeframes announced are so optimistic. If BFR can't be finished by 2025, competition with New Glenn would force SpaceX to delay it in favor of a smaller fully-reusable vehicle.

But the point is, it's still VERY early in BFR's development cycle, and they're still a ways from having a PDR at this point. So in the meantime, they can experiment with various concepts and stay in the news that way. But until they announce a configuration freeze, there's no reason to expect a Grasshopper version of BFS to launch fewer than 2 years from now.

The recent pivot to a Falcon-sized BFS for orbit reentry flights hints that the real thing will be sized to replace Falcon 9 and some FH launches. Not to launch 150 tonnes to LEO.

That's just my two cents as an aerospace engineer, though. :)

here's an an illustration of Apollo' s re entry trajectory to illustrate the method
https://www.hq.nasa.gov/pao/History/SP-4209/ch3-4.htm

The Germans were developing this sort of thing back in WW2, rather than re entering the atmosphere at max velocity, going strait down and trying to bleed off speed very quickly, creating a lot of heat and stress on the vehicle, they would sort of dip into the atmosphere and quasi surf, bounce off the atmosphere , using the wings to change the angle once they get some bite.. use that energy to skim along or even ascend a little, burning off speed, and doing this over and over again until going slow enough to enter like the falcon stages do.. Apollo did the same thing when coming in at 24, 000 miles an hour, they used thrusters to change the angle the capsule engaged the atmosphere, at times actually ascending during re entry.. apollo had the advantage of a blunt shape, shock wave that protected the vehicle, but she still got mad hot..
Space X is using this method to the nth degree, and since the vehicle is huge, and not as robust as apollo, those wings will slow the craft even further , providing for a gentler re entry ... the trick will be how they manage energy and heat around the Karman line, and keep it within limits.. It's like skipping a stone on sand paper, until the stone finally slows down to a manageable speed.. The Germans planned a space plane that skipped along the atmosphere after being launched by a bunch of V2 boosters,,
drop bombs on New York, and skip it's way back across the atmosphere around the world back to Germany.. all in like 2hrs..
It was the theoretical work from this program that allowed Nasa to use the same method to get around the high approach speed of lunar trajectories without having to use huge retro rockets to slow it down on approach to earth.. kind of surfed the atmosphere and used it as an aerodynamic brake.. Space X is suing the same method, but to a much greater degree, and with much tighter tolerances as the BFR is less tolerant of heat and friction, probably less so than the space shuttle.. so it will need a gentler , cooler approach..
The theory for this was already done in the 60's with the x15 program ,and "Dynasoar", where aircraft with no heat proofing tiles etc , managed to re enter the atmosphere after crossing the Karman line, all be it at much much lower speeds.. with the Advent of Pica, carbon fiber, titanium alloys, and nomex linings, and very very fast processors that can keep the vehicle on it's intended path , and manipulate those wings precisely and fast enough to maintain the correct attitudes ( a minor mistake at these speeds, even 10th's of a degree error will result in disaster).. the vehicle will either g out, and come apart, or skip off the atmosphere so hard it flies back into space .. having no fuel to re enter again.. just like Apollo.. though Apollo had a far greater margin for error as it was blunt and tough.. no protective shockwave for BFR, no ablative heat shield.. too much weight to make the vehicle viable.. this is going to be a dance with the Devil at the edge of the atmosphere.. with no room for error, very very difficult..very very cool..amazing tech.. good on Space X for tackling it.. the iterations we see in the design must be the result of Space X coming to conclusions about the viability of the size of the vehicle, and how much surface area is needed on those wings and provide a margin of safety.. the earlier lifting body type shapes we saw in 2016, 2017, may not have been proven or didn't stand up to tests in simulation.. I'm guessing the BFR shapes didn't provide enough control in certain critical phases of the decent, or added a lot of thrusters and complexity to the vehicle.. so they decided to go with larger wings.. plenty of fluid dynamic data available from the shuttle, it's proven and it works.. lifting body ? don't know of anybody that's ever done a re entry from orbit with one.. un charted territory, and space x would have to do all the R n D , build and test scale models , then hope it works and a bloody huge vehicle.. so we see it looking more like the shuttle..
I would love to know how this thing will manage heat, and how robust the airframe is , and how they get around issues of weight and complexity.. what it can bring to orbit is all well and good.. how it gets back..now that's interesting.. if Every Day could do a video on how the BFR will perform on re entry, and maybe his thoughts on the BFR's design .. that would be awesome..

I agree that you do not see very often inside the design process, but it is not unique: The Ocean Cleanup went through three very publicly visible design incarnations. First it was a 100-km-long barrier, fixed to the seabed, then multiple 2 km versions which were anchored at a few hundred meters depth and currently System 001 is 600 m in length, without any anchor as it is propelled by wind and waves.

Here's a question for future interviews with SpaceX planners: Why are they planning to land a large ship on Mars if early missions are planning to return, when John Houbolt's approach of a small lander was more weight efficient (Lunar Orbit Rendezvous, or in this case it's be Mars orbit rendezvous)? It seems all the eggs are in the basket that says fuel must be manufactured on the Mars surface for any of this to work.

If you look at the design process for the Apollo spacecraft and lunar lander, or for the Space Shuttle, you'd see a whole lot of rapid design changes as they gradually closed in on what was most practical for their performance/budget/time constraints. It is thus nothing new that the BFR/BFS likewise is going through several iterations before they actually start flight testing any of it.
Also, given SpaceX's (and Musk's) track record, they can probably accomplish it, but it is going to take more time and money than Musk's optimistic prediction. They may be aiming for a 2024 Mars launch, but it might take until 2030.

And another question. This question is related to a constraint from legacy rocket development. Curious Droid (see link below) makes the case that 'aerospike' engines would propel stuff (or people) to space more efficiently than the 'bell' engine design we use. He says, believably, that we aren't using the 'aerospike' design because of development, or "start-up," costs. In other words (my words) we can spend $1 today and launch future missions for $20 each with 'bell' engines or spend $5 today (developing aerospike) and launch future missions for $19.

A better way of expressing the trade off is that spending $5 today on developing the new engine would allow more efficient engines to haul bigger payloads. I think this is a better way to put it because saving fuel doesn't save as much as being able to launch the same size (recoverable) rocket with greater power.

I made up the numbers for 'start up,' and 'trade off' costs. For practical purposes the answer would depend on someone doing the arithmetic.

SpaceX announced in February 2017 that two people had signed up for a week long trek around the moon, which the company aimed to launch before the end of 2018. That mission was to use SpaceX's Dragon crew capsule and Falcon Heavy rocket. Had SpaceX followed through with that plan, it could have returned humans to the moon near the 50th anniversary of NASA's historic Apollo 8 mission around the moon in December 1968.

But this June, The Wall Street Journal reported that the flight had slipped into 2019 at the earliest. SpaceX representatives told that such a mission remained in the company's plans, but they didn't lay out a timeline or other details. Presumably, we will get a timeline on Monday and perhaps learn if the passenger flying on the BFR trip is one of the folks who signed up for the original Dragon-Falcon Heavy flight.

It's odd. Though I'm not a young digital native, I find the "public beta" style of engineering totally natural, and I think it should be done all the time. Currently, it's becoming pretty much the standard for video games, and increasingly for other consumer facing software. Seeing SpaceX do it seems natural to me, in keeping with the company's style. At the same time, it's really an extension of NASA's policy from the beginning - differentiating themselves from the Soviet space program by doing their work - and having their crashes - in full public view. This is the way it should be. I only wish it were more so. I wish Musk would appoint an ombudsperson whose job was to see how to make everything more public - to the limits of security. I mean, I love the launch webcasts, but they're terribly limited compared to what they could be. And after the fact, it would be fantastic to be able to see and compare every camera feed all the way through, rather than go with the choices made on the fly by their casters.

The redesigns seem like a cost-cutting measure. If you can send up the payload of one ITS over three BFR flights and have it cost less overall, then obviously go with the cheater option so long as the rocket quality remains the same.

The aft cargo modules are no where near large enough for major equipment, each one is only 7 and a 1/3rd m^3, which is significantly smaller then the container size that could be placed in the main cargo bay, which is itself far too small.

This is because the BFR has been designed as a passenger vehicle not a cargo vehicle. Their has been virtually no thought put into the logistics of how you move massive tonnage of habitats, vehicles and supplies out of this vehicle an onto the surface. In Antarctica we send C-130 Hercules and C-5 Galaxy transport planes capable of unloading multi-ton vehicles, and a Freighter ship carrying hundreds of 20ft containers, each person requiring on average 1 such container of supplies per year. Setting up a base in inhospitable terrain is a 99% Freight moving activity, but Musks design is trying to be a 747 which would unload passengers at an existing settlement like they were tourists with nothing but some suitcases.

The only design that makes sense is one that has a LOW cargo hold which can deploy a ramp for roll-on roll-off operations. Eliminate integrated passengers sections and put passengers in a hab module that can be rolled off onto the surface and then return the vehicle to Earth empty. When people need to return to Earth roll the habitat back in the vehicle.

I have suggested an LFS in the past as a second stage for the Falcon 9.  The suggestion is more valid today.  SpaceX has to test their ideas as they evolve, and having a miniature BFS would be perfect.  You launch satellites up to 3 tons with it, it has 7 mini raptors, and the loss of the vehicle will be less costly than the loss of a full size BFS.  Testing can be done of the heat shield, the fins, the landing gear, reentry trajectory, and refueling.  Then it can be scaled up to the BFR, and either the LFS is abandoned, sold to a competitor for small sat launch, or kept as a proof of concept.  You have Elon's ear, so you could suggest it... that is after you went through it to see if the idea has merit, or is even viable.

BTW, by constantly asking question, it is easy to see why there are design changes; since this is a new 'one-off' design, it will most certainly run into unknowns and re-designs. It is likely that there will never be a reusable single model design, ever... from the first launch, design changes will continue as we/they continually face new insights, revelations, and critical issues -- the very nature of space exploration; from our experience, and perhaps into the 23rd Century, will be plagued with unknowns and continued/forced design changes along the way -- it will always be by 'Trial-and-Error' -- hopefully, they'll catch most of the critical 'errors' before launch. The basic facts are; while rocket designs and space exploration is in reality still in its infancy, there are still countless uncertainties that haven't yet been discussed or imagined. The challenge for engineers and physicist is, will they be ready to deal with them in a predictive way before launch? Some things that nature throws our way are in reality non-intuitive, and this is the risk that they'll face.

my understanding is that the rd-180 already had crazy high chamber pressures, in fact, if memory serves correct NASA and the USA in general, used it, despite this, because it has proven to be very reliable, amongst other things

EDIT: I speculate that Spacex believes they can get away with 300 bar because it is 3D printed-- unlike the traditional construction where dozens of milled superalloy parts are welded together. While flawless welds can be made, they cannot be made 100% of the time, therefore a rather large safety factor has to be made for it. In 3D printing, the entire structure is welded; but it is just one weld. Not all of them will be flawless, but some will, unlike traditionally made rocket engines that will have a flaw somewhere in all of them.

There's just one thing I wanted to say: control surfaces don't work by generating drag, they work by generating lift, so they absolutely are aerodynamic surfaces, using the same term you used! Hi Tim @Everyday Astronaut

Important to note: the fins give drag, but not much compared to the hull. Their real purpose is stabilization and maneouvering. Just as Elon said, it's like a skydiver (very good comparison). Moving them "upwards" or to the "vertical" (rearwards in direction of flight), makes them give less drag and provide natural static stability on roll axis.

If the vehicle rollsto a side, that side's fin and cannard get more perpendicular to airflow, having more drag and making the vessel roll back to 0.

For pitching up, cannards can be put more horizontally and/or rear fins more vertically to make the nose more draggy than the tail, the opposite for pitching down.

For yawing, left cannard and right fin can be moved opposite to right cannard and left fin, deflecting air more to one side than to the other.

Also, all four surfaces can be moved to provide more or less drag and control the downrange distance.

It's a neat flight control system that can perform all those corrections without using RCS. It's awesome!

Love the rundown! A few interesting things:

- Elon mentioned that the AFT cargo bays can be switched for vacuum engines. This means that SpaceX can focus on streamlining the BFR without having to design it from scratch later. Vacuum engines are good for increasing mass to orbit, so they probably figured out that 100 tons are good enough at first. When the vacuum engines are switched in, we will see far more than a "mere" 100 ton LEO launch capability.

- The AFT cargo bays are great for storing Starlink satellites. This means that SpaceX can run launches for customers while sending their own satellites up AT THE SAME TIME! Again, they probably don't need vacuum engines to do this, so it's a really clever solution.

- Considering the points above, we will probably see two (or more?) versions of BFR in the future: A version with sea level engines only and a vacuum version. The sea level version will be great for Starlink/light duty delivery and personnel delivery/tourism; especially point-to-point flights on Earth. The main BFS could carry passengers, while AFT cargo could carry trade-goods. The vacuum version will be great for heavy duty hauls (like new space stations) and long hauls to other places in the solar system.

I mention the shuttle because that was the only real reusable space craft that was used.

So, to me the re-entry method for the BFS does not seem particularly new. This seems to be the same basic idea as the space shuttle. Now the big "gotcha" here is how does a re-entering BFS density compare to the space shuttle? Let's hope the BFS is quite a bit less dense than the shuttle, otherwise the BFS will still need substantial retro thrust applied, or some really good thermal protection. Neither of which seems like the plan right now.

tl;dr the re-entry method isn't new, it's just aerobraking.

I am displeased with them changing things constantly, it tells me they still have no clue how to solve the orbit to vertical landing problem. Going from >16,500 mph in a belly flop configuration, handling the heat and g-load and then flipping to vertical landing at 0 mph is a very difficult problem. Being able to angle up and down those wings is a totally new problem, the forces on those wings is insane (I think elon admitted it would be in the meganewtons) and that means an actuator that can fight that.

One simpler solution would be to just land horizontal with horizontal engines, but that requires new engines that only function for landing and are dead weight the rest of the time.
